bug.author: StevenPuttemans
bug.summary: opencv2 header not including everything in standard library
bug.description:
Is there a reason why adding #include "opencv2\opencv.hpp" excludes several modules? For example using the stitcher only works if you combine it with the specific header like follows <denchmark-code>#include "opencv2/opencv.hpp" #include "opencv2/stitching.hpp" </denchmark-code>
Since the stitching module is in the core library and not in the contributed modules, my opinion is that it should get included using the opencv.hpp header...

comments.comment: <denchmark-link:https://github.com/alalek>@alalek</denchmark-link> does this tag means that the dev team actually agrees on this? If so I can simply provide a pull request, but I was wondering what the team would think!

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/StevenPuttemans>@StevenPuttemans</denchmark-link> , this tag means that a comment from core team or other appropriate person is needed. As I can see, the include which should be generated by cmake from <denchmark-link:https://github.com/opencv/opencv/blob/master/cmake/templates/opencv_modules.hpp.in>the template</denchmark-link> . Does it contain needed module?

I guess there lies the problem. After building OpenCV, the content of my auto generated opencv_modules.hpp found at /usr/local/include/opencv2/ after doing a sudo make install is <denchmark-code>/* * ** File generated automatically, do not modify ** * * This file defines the list of modules available in current build configuration * * */
#define HAVE_OPENCV_CALIB3D #define HAVE_OPENCV_CORE #define HAVE_OPENCV_FEATURES2D #define HAVE_OPENCV_FLANN #define HAVE_OPENCV_HIGHGUI #define HAVE_OPENCV_IMGCODECS #define HAVE_OPENCV_IMGPROC #define HAVE_OPENCV_ML #define HAVE_OPENCV_OBJDETECT #define HAVE_OPENCV_PHOTO #define HAVE_OPENCV_SHAPE #define HAVE_OPENCV_STITCHING #define HAVE_OPENCV_SUPERRES #define HAVE_OPENCV_VIDEO #define HAVE_OPENCV_VIDEOIO #define HAVE_OPENCV_VIDEOSTAB </denchmark-code>
So basically the defines are there, but not the includes that need to be in between them :D looks like a bug to me!

Yes, I agree. Feel free to provide pull request with a fix. BTW, if you add -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=install parameter when running cmake, then make install will put all files to build/install folder without modifying system libraries and headers. It can be useful for experimenting.
Ah good to know! Will take a closer look why the generation is not working correctly!
